title: Integration – Reading and Translation
goals: Combine –āre and –ēre verbs in reading practice
Check agreement of subjects and verbs
Apply virtue of Prudentia through careful attention

steps.speak: Salve! Let’s warm up both families. Chant –āre: amō, amās, amat … and –ēre: videō, vidēs, videt …
Excellent! Now listen to this sentence: Puella videt aquam et laudat Deum.
Translate it together: The girl sees the water and praises God.
Notice: videt is Second Conjugation, laudat is First. Two families working together!
Next: Puer habet librum et amat sapientiam. What does that mean?
Answer: The boy has a book and loves wisdom. Bene!
Make your own short sentence with an –āre and an –ēre verb. Say it in Latin, then in English.
Copywork: videō, vidēs, videt / amō, amās, amat – one neat line each.
Faith phrase: Deus videt – God sees. Reflect – what does God see in your diligent work today?
Virtue reminder: Prudentia is wise seeing. When we read and translate carefully, we practice wisdom.
Excellent! Tomorrow we will finish Week 12 with a mastery check and celebration.
